Graphical abstract Influence of cesium and vanadium contents on the oxidation functionalities of heteropoly molybdate catalysts Keggin-type heteropoly molybdates with different cesium and vanadium contents were synthesized and characterized by X-ray diffraction, FT-infrared, in situ Laser Raman, X-ray photo electron spectroscopy and temperature programmed desorption of NH3 techniques. The catalytic functionalities were evaluated for vapor phase aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol. Raman spectral studies suggest the partial destabilization of Keggin structure of the catalyst with more than two vanadium atoms per one Keggin unit in the primary structure. The conversion of benzyl alcohol and selectivity to benzaldehyde was influenced by both Cs and V contents. The correlation between catalytic activity and physico-chemical properties of the catalysts suggested that the acidity and redox nature of the catalysts have an important role in the oxidation of benzyl alcohol and these properties are influenced by the amounts of Cs and V, respectively, in heteropoly molybdates. A plausible mechanism for Cs x MPAV y /TiO2 catalyzed oxidation of benzyl alcohol has been proposed. Keywords Benzyl alcohol Cesium Molybdophosphoric acid Oxidation Titania Vanadia 1 Introduction Selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes is an important reaction in both fundamental research and industrial manufacturing point of view [1]. The world-wide annual production of carbonyl compounds is over 107 tons and most of these compounds are produced from oxidation of alcohols [2]. This functional group transformation can be accomplished by a number of diverse methods. However, many of the processes in practise are hazardous as they produce toxic waste in stoichiometric amounts. Traditionally, these transformations have been performed with stoichiometric inorganic oxidants, notably chromium(VI) and manganese(VII) reagents [3]. Growing environmental restrictions are forcing the shutdown of such hazardous processes. Over the years, constant innovations in catalyst and process design have resulted in a number of new developments for improving economics and eco-friendliness. In this context, many of the researchers have been focusing on the use of environmentally benign heterogeneous catalysts, such as, supported noble metals [4,5], complexes of transition metals [6,7], and solid acids [8,9]. The application of solid catalysts for the oxidation of alcohol was reviewed in detail by Mallat and Baiker [10]. Among the different available solid acid catalysts, heteropoly acids (HPAs) have attracted considerable attention in recent times [11,12]. Heteropoly acids with Keggin structure have been intensively studied as green oxidation catalysts for both heterogeneous and homogeneous processes due to their unique acidic and redox properties [13–15]. The main advantage of these heteropolyacids is that their acid and redox properties can be tuned in a systematic way by changing their molecular composition. However, due to low thermal stability, surface area and high solubility in polar solvents, HPAs cannot be used as heterogeneous catalysts in their pure form. In order to make these heterogeneous, three kinds of modifications can be done which are viz., (i) exchanging the protons present in secondary structure with large cations, such as Cs+, NH4 +, etc., (ii) incorporating redox atoms, such as V, Nb into the primary structure in place of addenda atoms, (iii) dispersing HPAs on stable supports. The acidity of HPAs can be customized by secondary structure modification while redox nature can be altered by primary structure modification. Partial alkali exchanged HPAs exhibit dramatic changes in surface area, pore size, acidity and thermal stability. Salts with large monovalent ions, such as Cs+, NH4 +, Rb+ and Ag+ are practically insoluble in water or other polar solvents and possess high surface areas [15,16]. Incorporation of V, Nb, etc., in place of addenda atom enhances redox nature of the catalysts. The role of Cs and V atoms present in heteropoly molybdate catalysts have reported for the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane [17]. The oxidation activity decreased significantly with increasing cesium content (2–4) over Cs x H3−x PMo12O40 and Cs x H4−x PVMo11O40 catalysts with different cesium contents. Lee et al. [18] studied the catalysts with fixed Cs+ and variables (0, 1, 2) vanadium contents for the reaction of oxidative dehydrogenation of isobutyric acid to methacrylic acid and reported that acidity and redox nature of the catalysts are essential for the better performance of the catalysts. The influence of Cs and V contents in heteropoly molybdates toward oxidation of methacrolein to methacrylic acid was studied and highlighted the drawbacks of these catalysts [19]. It has also been reported that the introduction of vanadium at the primary structure of Keggin anion of molybdophosphates can enhance the catalytic activity and a small fraction of vanadium can be segregated in the form of (VO)2+ during the reaction [20]. The addition of vanadium species to the secondary structure can result in a much more active and selective catalyst for acrylic acid production during partial oxidation of propane. Majority of these reports deals with bulk catalysts and further studies are needed to shed light on the role of Cs and V contents on oxidation properties of supported cesium salts of vanado molybdophosphate catalyst systems. In the present study, heteropoly molybdates are modified by exchanging its protons with Cs+ ions, incorporating V atoms in place of Mo and dispersing them on TiO2 support. The oxidation functionalities of these catalysts were tested for vapor phase oxidation of benzyl alcohol using air as oxidant. The influence of Cs, V present in the primary and secondary structures of heteropoly molybdates, respectively, for their oxidation activity is explored. A plausible mechanism for Cs x MPAV y /TiO2 catalyzed oxidation of benzyl alcohol has been proposed. The catalytic activities were correlated with the textural properties obtained from different characterization results. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of H3+y PMo12−y V y O40/TiO2 catalyst Vanadium incorporated molybdophosphoric acid catalysts H3+y PMo12−y V y O40 (y =1, 2, 3) were prepared according to the reported procedure [21]. The detailed method of H4PMo11V1O40 (MPAV1) preparation was explained elsewhere [22]. Preparation of H5PMo10V2O40 (MPAV2) and H6PMo9V3O40 (MPAV3) catalysts is also similar to that of MPAV1 except by taking the required amount of sodium metavanadate and sodium molybdate. Titania (Loba Chemie, India) supported catalysts were prepared by impregnation method. The required quantity of MPAV y (y =1, 2, 3) was dissolved in minimum amount of water, and this solution was added to support with constant stirring. The excess water was removed using water bath and the catalyst masses were dried in an air oven at 120°C for 12h. These catalysts were denoted as MPAV y /TiO2 (y =1, 2, 3). The samples used for activity studies are calcined at 350°C for 4h in air. The active component content on TiO2 was kept constant at 20wt% for all the catalysts. 2.1.2 Preparation of Cs x H3+y−x PMo12−y V y O40/TiO2 catalyst The protons present in the above prepared catalysts were exchanged with cesium by using cesium nitrate (CsNO3) as precursor. The required quantity of CsNO3 dissolved in water was added drop wise to MPAV y /TiO2 to exchange the protons of MPAV y with Cs. The excess water was removed on water bath and the final catalysts were obtained by calcining at 350°C for 4h. The content of Cs was varied from 1 to 3 moles to replace equivalent protons in MPAV y . The catalysts are denoted as CsxMPAVy/TiO2, where the x indicates the number of Cs ions substituted for proton and y indicates number of V atoms substituted for Mo. 2.2 Catalysts characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Rigaku Miniflex diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (1.5406A°) at 40kV and 30mA and secondary graphite monochromatic. The measurements were obtained in steps of 0.045° with a count time of 0.5s and in the 2θ range of 10–80 degrees. Raman spectra were recorded at room temperature in the range of 200–1200cm−1 using a Horiba Jobin-Yvon Lab Ram HR spectrometer of a 17mW internal He–Ne (Helium–Neon) Laser source with excitation wavelength of 632.8nm. The catalyst samples in powder form (about 5–10mg) were loosely spread onto a glass slide below the confocal microscope for Raman measurements. In situ Raman spectra of the catalyst were recorded by the same Raman spectrometer equipped with high-temperature catalyst cell reactor (Linkam CCP 1000) using 50X long working distance objective. The catalyst sample, typically consisting between 10 and 15mg of loose powder, was placed in an environmentally controlled high-temperature cell reactor containing a quartz window. The temperature of the reactor cell was controlled by programmable temperature controller. Temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (TPD) was carried out on a laboratory-built apparatus equipped with a gas chromatograph using thermal conductivity detector. In a typical experiment, about 0.1g of the oven dried sample was taken in a quartz tube and treated at 300°C for 1h by passing pure helium (99.9%, 50ml/min). After pretreatment, the sample was saturated with anhydrous ammonia (10% NH3 balanced with He) with a flow of 50mL/min at 100°C for 1h and was subsequently flushed with He at the same temperature to remove physisorbed ammonia. The process was continued until a stabilized base line was obtained in the gas chromatograph. Then the TPD analysis was carried out by programming the temperature from 100 to 600°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted on a KRATOS AXIS 165 with a DUAL anode (Mg and Al) apparatus using Mg Kα anode. The non-monochromatized Al Kα X-ray source (hυ=1486.6eV) was operated at 12.5kV and 16mA. Before acquisition of the data, each sample was out-gassed for about 3h at 100°C under vacuum of 1.0×10−7 T to minimize surface contamination. The XPS instrument was calibrated using Au as standard. For energy calibration, the carbon 1s photoelectron line was used. The carbon 1s binding energy was taken as 285eV. Charge neutralization of 2eV was used to balance the charge up of the sample. The spectra were deconvoluted using Sun Solaris Vision-2 curve resolver. The location and the full width at half maximum (FWHM) value for the species were first determined using the spectrum of a pure sample. Symmetric Gaussian shapes were used in all cases. Binding energies for identical samples were, in general, reproducible within ±0.1eV. 31P nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra of solids were recorded in a 400MHz Bruker spectrometer. A 4.5μs pulse (90°) was used with repetition time of 5s between pulses in order to avoid saturation effects. Spinning rate was 5kHz. All the measurements were carried out at room temperature using 85% H3PO4 as standard reference. 2.3 Catalyst activity measurements Aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol was carried out in a fixed bed vertical glass reactor (h =350mm, d =12mm) under atmospheric pressure. In a typical experiment, about 0.5g of catalyst (crushed to a particle size of 18/25 BSS mesh to avoid mass transfer limitations), diluted with same size and volume of quartz beads, was loaded in the reactor. Prior to reaction, catalyst was pretreated in air at 300°C. The reaction was carried by flowing air (60mLmin−1) and benzyl alcohol (2mLh−1) supplied through a syringe pump (B. Braun, Germany). The reaction was carried at different temperatures in the range of 250–310°C. After attaining steady state condition over a period of 1h, the condensable reaction products were collected (by cooling up to −10°C) and analyzed by gas chromatography using SE-30 column and flame ionization detector. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Cs x MPAV1/TiO2 catalysts X-ray diffraction patterns of 20% Cs x MPAV1/TiO2 (x =0, 1, 2, 3) catalysts along with support TiO2 are shown in Fig. 1 . The diffraction patterns are seen at 2θ values of 25.2°, 37.9°, 48.1°, 53.9°, 55.1° and 62.7° corresponding to anatase phase of titania [23]. The major reflections corresponding to Keggin ion are overlapped with characteristic reflection of titania. However, weak reflections corresponding to Keggin CsMPAV1 are seen at 10.6, 30.4 and 35.6° indicating that the crystallization of HPAs has started at this 20wt% which is in accordance with the reported results [24]. The reflection at 35.6° corresponds to protonated form of MPA. Intensity of this peak decreases by supporting on metal oxides or by making them corresponding salts [22]. Similar phenomenon was reported recently on samarium salts of tungstophosphoric acid [25]. As the samples used in present study are cesium salts and TiO2 supported, the intensity of this peak is very less. The absence of patterns corresponding to oxides of Keggin constituent metals (Mo, V, P) indicates that intact Keggin ion of CsMPAV1 is present on the support. FT-IR spectra of the catalysts along with pure MPA are shown in Fig. 2 . The TiO2 support absorbs IR signal below 850cm−1 that prevents collection of Keggin vibrations in this region. The catalysts with different Cs+ contents showed characteristic IR bands of Keggin ion at 1065, 965 and 863cm−1 which are assigned to asymmetric vibrations of POa (Oa =oxygen atoms bound to three Mo atoms and to P) MoOt (Ot =terminal oxygen), MoOb Mo (Ob =corner sharing bridging oxygen), respectively [26]. In the spectra of present catalysts, the band corresponding to MoOb Mo stretching mode is slightly shifted to lower wave number relative to that of pure HPMo12 (from 870 to 863cm−1). This shift is due to vanadium incorporation into primary structure forms MoOV linkages by replacing Mo from MoOMo bonds of MPA. The bond strength decreases by replacing Mo6+ with V5+ which intern responsible for the shift in the stretching frequency toward lower values. Interestingly, a marginal shift in the position of POa band of Keggin ion for vanadium containing samples toward lower wave numbers (blue shift) was noticed in the spectrum. This shift is due to the influence of vanadium on the MO bond and thereby results in the change of structure symmetry [27]. Another characteristic band corresponding to MoOc Mo of Keggin structure was absent in the spectra as it is in the IR absorption region of TiO2. These results confirm that the Keggin structure remains intact even after protons are exchanged with Cs+ ions. Fig. 3 shows the Raman spectra of Cs x MPAV1/TiO2 catalysts. The characteristic bands of titania are dominant in the spectra. Hence, all the characteristic bands of Keggin were not seen. The predominant bands observed at 392, 510 and 632cm−1 in all the samples are assigned to anatase phase of TiO2 [28,29]. The characteristic Raman bands of Keggin ion are shown in the inset of the Fig. 3 for the sake of clarity. These bands are shifted toward lower values i.e., observed at ∼988 and 970cm−1 for current samples. The observed red shift in present samples can be ascribed to presence of cesium ions in the secondary structure. Similar red shift with exchanging the protons by large cesium ions was reported [30]. Thus, the Raman results clearly endorse the presence of intact CsMPAV Keggin ion on titania. 31P MAS-NMR spectral analysis was carried to know the substitution of V atom in place of Mo in the primary structure of heteropoly molybadate and the spectrum of Cs2MPAV1/TiO2 is shown in Fig. 4 . The spectral data showed a chemical shift at −3.28ppm. The chemical shift for the supported MPA catalysts (without V atoms) was observed at −3.61ppm [31]. When one Mo6+ atom is substituted by one V5+ atom in heteropoly molybdate Keggin ion, a displacement of chemical shift to lower fields will be observed [32]. The 31P MAS-NMR spectra data suggests the presence of V5+ in the primary structure of Cs2MPAV1/TiO2 catalyst. The TPD patterns of Cs x MPAV1/TiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 and the corresponding acidity values are presented in Table 1 . In general, acidity of heteropoly molybdates varies with modification of primary and/or secondary structures. As shown in Table 1, TiO2 supported MPA sample showed highest acidity and the acidity decreased with incorporating V atoms and exchange of Cs+ ions. When one V incorporated into the primary structure of MPA (i.e., MPAV1/TiO2) marginal fall in acidity was noticed from 0.26 to 0.20mmol/g. In the case of Cs exchanged MPAV1/TiO2 catalysts, proton exchange with Cs+ caused a sudden fall in acidity. Further increase in Cs+ content leads to increase in acidity marginally up to 2Cs+ ions beyond which acidity value decreases. Similar results were also observed by Sun et al. [17] on Cs x H4-x PMo11VO40 catalysts. More specifically, they have reported that the acidity increases with Cs content up to 2.5 beyond which it decreases. It has been well reported that the desorption peaks below 327°C correspond to desorption of NH3 adsorbed on weak Lewis acid sites and the peak above this temperature corresponds to the desorption of NH3 adsorbed on strong Bronsted acid sites [17]. All the catalysts exhibited a low temperature desorption peak around 195°C, related to the weak Lewis acidic sites of the samples. The catalysts showed a major broad peak at 450°C which can be attributed to moderate and strong Bronsted acidity resulting from surface TiOH hydroxyl groups and/or residual protons of HPAs. Binding of NH3 on the Bronsted sites makes the HPAs as their ammonium salts which intern is responsible for high temperature desorption. Intensity of this peak was found to decrease with increase in Cs+ content. This could be ascribed to the lowering of number of protons with the replacement by Cs+ ions. Similar discussion has also been reported by other researchers [17,27]. 3.2 Oxidation of benzyl alcohol Benzyl alcohol undergoes different transformations during the oxidation based on the nature of catalyst. The main reactions are: 2C6H5CH2OH+O2 →2C6H5CHO+2H2O (1) 2C6H5CH2OH→C6H5CH2OCH2C6H5 +H2O (2) 2C6H5CH2OH→C6H5CHO+C6H5CH3 +H2O (3) C6H5CH2OH+C6H5CH3 →C6H5CH2CH2C6H5 +H2O (4) The formation of benzaldehyde depends on the oxidation ability of the catalyst. The formation of dibenzyl ether, diphenyl ethane (dimer of benzyl alcohol) and the disproportionation of benzyl alcohol depend on the acidic nature of the catalyst [33–35]. When the acidic nature is dominating, dimer product formation will be facilitated and with increase in redox nature, partial oxidization product formation will be facilitated. Formation of dimer can be understood with the help of following hypothesis: when excess toluene is formed due to the acidic sites of catalysts, it undergoes condensation with benzyl alcohol molecules to form dimer product. 3.2.1 Effect of Cs+ content in CsMPAV1/TiO2 catalysts The catalytic activities of Cs x MPAV1/TiO2 catalysts with different Cs contents are evaluated for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol and the results are displayed in Fig. 6 . The activity data of MPAV1/TiO2 (without Cs) also included for comparison. Conversion of benzyl alcohol increased with increase in Cs content up to 2. Further increase in Cs content leads to a marginal decrease in activity. However, selectivity followed reverse trend. Interestingly high amount of benzyl alcohol dimer was formed at a Cs content of 2 and diminished for the catalyst with more Cs content. The formation of polybenzyl was noticed by earlier researchers during benzyl alcohol oxidation over heteropoly acids [35]. Rocchiccioli-Deltcheff and Fournier studied the influence of microwave (MW) power and irradiation times on condensation products and revealed that with increasing MW power and irradiation times, yield of polybenzyl increased over heteropoly acids [36]. The formation of dimer can be correlated to the acidity values of the catalysts. The relatively high acidity of Cs2MPAV1/TiO2 catalyst may be responsible for the formation of condensation product. The lowering of benzyl alcohol conversion and selectivity to diphenylethane (dimer) for the catalysts with change in Cs content from Cs2 to Cs3 can be ascribed to the decrease in acidity. It clearly indicates that acidity of the catalysts is playing a crucial role on the benzyl alcohol conversion and selectivity to the desired product benzaldehyde. The presence of Cs improved acidity of catalysts and thereby conversion of benzyl alcohol. However, the selectivity to benzaldehyde is limited. It is intended to study the role of V content which supposes to enhance the oxidation ability due to its redox nature. 3.2.2 Effect of V content in Cs2MPAV y /TiO2 catalysts The Cs2MPAV y /TiO2 catalysts with varying the number of V atoms in primary structure are evaluated for benzyl alcohol oxidation and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . An increase in activity was observed with incorporation of V into the primary structure of Cs2MPA/TiO2 catalyst. When two vanadium atoms were substituted into the primary structure, a considerable decrease in conversion of benzyl alcohol was noticed whilst the selectivity to benzaldehyde increased. Further increase in V content leads to a considerable increase in selectivity to benzaldehyde and decrease in the conversion of benzyl alcohol. 3.2.3 Effect of reaction temperature The variation of catalytic activity with reaction temperature for the Cs2MPAV2/TiO2 catalyst was shown in Fig. 8 . Conversion of benzyl alcohol increased with reaction temperature and this enhancement is high with increase in temperature from 250 to 270°C. The change in conversion of benzyl alcohol is very low within the temperature range 270–310°C. Selectivity to benzaldehyde decreased with increasing reaction temperature and this decrease is considerable from 250 to 270°C. The decrease in selectivity to benzaldehyde was compensated by the formation of diphenylethane. 3.2.4 Time on stream analysis The stability of the present catalysts during the oxidation of benzyl alcohol was studied by time on stream analysis. The conversion and selectivity values obtained with reaction time are plotted in Fig. 9 . It is worth mentioning that the catalysts exhibited constant activity with retaining its selectivity in the entire period of 10h. In order to understand the role of V atoms in primary structure of Cs2MPAVy/TiO2 catalysts, these catalysts are further characterized. 3.3 Characterization of Cs2MPAV y /TiO2 catalysts Raman spectra of Cs2MPAVy/TiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 10 . The main bands related to Keggin ion are shown in inset of the Fig. 9. In addition to the major band, a weak broad band was noticed at ∼820cm−1. The intensity of the bands increased with increase in V atoms in the primary structure of MPA. These bands ascribed to α-MoO3 species which are formed by the partial disintegration of Keggin structure. The intensity of this band increased with more number of V atoms in the primary structure. It is well documented that the presence of more number of V atoms destabilizes the Keggin ion [36,37]. The NH3-TPD patterns of Cs2MPAVy/TiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 11 and the acidity values are displayed in Table 1. The increase in number of V atoms in primary structure of Keggin leads to decrease in the total acidity of the samples. This could be due to the enhanced redox nature due to the presence of more V atoms in primary structure and partial destabilization of MPA Keggin structure beyond the second V atom in the primary structure. In order to understand the influence of cesium on thermal stability of titania supported vanadium incorporated heteropoly molybdates, 20% Cs2MPAV2/TiO2 and 20% MPAV2/TiO2 samples were subjected to thermal treatment under in situ Raman conditions and the spectra of these samples are shown in Fig. 12 (A) and (B), respectively. As the predominate peaks are due to titania, the characteristic peaks of Keggin ion are shown in the inset of the figures. The Raman spectra of MPAV2/TiO2 sample recorded at increasing temperature has shown the decomposition of Keggin structure. The major peak at 817cm−1 observed at high temperature treatment could be assigned to MoOMo stretching mode of α-MoO3 [38]. The appearance of broad band at 817cm−1 indicates that degradation started at 550°C and led to formation of α-MoO3 at high temperature. Complete degradation of Keggin structure was noticed at a temperature of 750°C. Another intense Raman band was observed at 992cm−1 assigned to terminal MoO stretching mode of α-MoO3 and VO stretching of bulk vanadia [38,39]. The weak band observed at 237cm−1 can be assigned to the combination of deformation mode of isopoly anions and rutile TiO2. The weak Raman band at 334cm−1 can be attributed to the combination of OMO (MMo, V) bending vibrations of α-MoO3 and V2O5. The Raman band at 285cm−1 is also assigned to a combination band of both α-MoO3 and V2O5 [38,39]. The decrease in the intensity of characteristic TiO2 peaks at higher temperatures may be due to phase transformation of TiO2 from anatase to rutile. In the case of Cs2MPAV2/TiO2 catalyst decomposition was not observed at 550°C and partial degradation was observed only at elevated temperatures. Thus the presence of cesium ions in MPAV led to increase in its thermal stability. The XPS technique is widely used surface characterization technique to analyze the metal oxidation states of solid inorganic material. The binding energies (BEs) of various core-electron levels (O 1s, P 2p, Ti 2p, V 2p, and Mo 3d) for fresh and used samples of 20% Cs2MPAV2/TiO2 catalyst are summarized in Table 2 . The BEs for the P 2p core level for fresh and used samples are in the region of 133.6–134.1eV, indicating that phosphorus is a phosphate [40,41]. The BEs for the Ti 2p core level in fresh sample are observed at 459.8eV and 465.3eV, suggesting that the oxidation state of titanium is Ti4+ [41,42]. The BEs are decreased by 0.7eV in the case of used samples which indicates the reduction of Ti4+ to lower oxidation states during the course of reaction. Two well-defined peaks of the O 1s core level are noticed for these catalysts among which the first peak is attributed to oxygen of TiO2 support, and the latter one is due to MoOMo, MoOP, and/or MoOH in polymolybdate structures [41,43]. The BEs of these two peaks are found to be increased during the course of reaction by 0.6eV. The observed BE values of Mo 3d for both fresh and used samples can be attributed to Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 core levels [40,44]. The BEs are shifting toward lower values during the course of reaction indicating that Mo is undergoing reduction [44]. The BEs of V 2p3/2 and V 2p1/2 core levels for fresh sample at 517.9 and 524.5eV are characteristic of V5+ [45]. These peaks were shifted to lower binding energies in the case of used sample indicating that the V is undergoing reduction to its lower oxidation states during the course of reaction [44]. Thus, it can be stated that the lattice oxygen is participating in the reaction and catalyst gets reduced during the reaction [44]. It is essential to understand the influence of cesium and vanadium content in enhancing the oxidization ability of the TiO2 supported heteropoly molybdates. XRD, FT-IR, Laser Raman results confirmed the presence of intact Keggin structure over the surface of titania. Increase in cesium content in Cs x MPAV1/TiO2 catalyst resulted a raise in conversion of benzyl alcohol till two Cs+ ions and then decreased further increase in Cs content. Acidity measurements from NH3-TPD provide crucial justification for this observed trend of activity. It is well known that acidity of cesium salts of heteropolyacids increases with cesium content till 2 or 2.5 Cs+ ions, thereafter it decreases which is due to the high mobility of the protons [46,47]. It is also observed from the Table 1 that incorporation of V into the primary structure led to a significant decrease in the acidity and subsequent enhancement in redox nature of the sample. Intact Keggin structure and mobile protons might be responsible for high activity of C2MPAV1/TiO2 catalyst. The strong acidity of Cs2MPAV1/TiO2 catalyst is responsible for the limited selectivity to benzaldehyde and formation of diphenyl ethane and toluene. Further studies on influence of vanadium atoms in the primary structure of heteropoly acids revealed that Cs2MPAV2/TiO2 catalyst can be regarded as better one by considering the yields of desired product benzaldehyde. This could be due to the enhanced redox nature due to vanadium present in the primary structure. Though the selectivity to benzaldehyde increased with further V incorporation, conversion decreased which is due to the partial disintegration of the Keggin structure. The partial disintegration of the Keggin structure is supported by Raman analysis. Thus it can be stated that the reasonable amount of Cs and V which directs the stability, acidity and redox nature of heteropoly molybdates as suitable catalysts for oxidation reactions. The plausible mechanistic illustration for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol is presented in the Scheme 1 . The proposed mechanism suggests the participation of both acidic and redox centers of the catalysts in the oxidation reaction. The first step is that an electrophilic attack of acidic proton associated with Keggin unit on the oxygen atom of benzyl alcohol to form protonated benzyl alcohol species. The formation of such intermediate on H3PW12O40 for methanol oxidation was evidenced from IR spectral measurements by Highfield and Moffat [48]. The increase of catalytic activity with acidity of the catalysts supports this step. The second step involves nucleophilic attack of a lone pair of neighboring Keggin bridging oxygen on the positively charged carbon atoms results in CO bond cleavage, H2O removal and benzyl group attached to the bridging oxygen of Keggin unit. In the third step, abstraction of benzylic proton by adjacent bridging oxygen and further rearrangement of electrons results in the formation of carbonyl carbon with bridging oxygen. Further, desorption of benzaldehyde molecule leaves behind an oxygen deficient, partially reduced catalyst. The re-oxidation of catalyst takes place with the oxygen. According to Bruckman et al., progress of oxidation reaction depends on the rate of H abstraction from adsorbed 1-phenyl methoxy group [37] which intern depends on the electron density present over the bridging oxygen. It is well known that the electron density of bridging oxygen of MoOMo bond type increases with number of vanadium atoms. Therefore, it can be stated that the H abstraction is more favorable in the sample with two vanadium atoms substituted for Mo atoms in Keggin structure. The proposed mechanism is supported by the XPS studies performed on fresh and used samples of best catalyst (20% Cs2MPAV2/TiO2). Participation of lattice oxygen in the reaction and as a consequence, creation of oxygen vacancy causes the reduction of catalyst which is evidenced from the XPS findings. Hence, it can be stated that the reaction is following Mars–van-Krevelen mechanism. This mechanism was also supported many recent literature reports on selective oxidation reactions over vanadium containing heteropoly molybdate catalysts [44,49–51]. 4 Conclusions To summarize, the catalytic performances of cesium exchanged MPAV y /TiO2 catalysts depend on the amount of Cs and V present in heteropoly molybdate. The appropriate selection of Cs and V composition in these catalysts is a pivotal factor for the superior performance of the Cs x MPAV y /TiO2 catalysts. The exceptional activity of Cs2MPAV1/TiO2 catalyst with limited selectivity to desired product is mainly due to the high mobility of protons. The substantial decrease in the activity and increment in selectivity to benzaldehyde with second V atom incorporation is due to decrease in mobility of the protons and enhancement in redox nature. The thermal stability of heteropoly molybdates during aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol can be enhanced by converting them into cesium salts. coredata.dc:description: Keggin-type heteropoly molybdates with different cesium and vanadium contents were synthesized and characterized by X-ray diffraction, FT-infrared, in situ Laser Raman, X-ray photo electron spectroscopy and temperature programmed desorption of NH3 techniques. The catalytic functionalities were evaluated for vapor phase aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol. Raman spectral studies suggest the partial destabilization of Keggin structure of the catalyst with more than two vanadium atoms per one Keggin unit in the primary structure. The conversion of benzyl alcohol and selectivity to benzaldehyde was influenced by both Cs and V contents. The correlation between catalytic activity and physico-chemical properties of the catalysts suggested that the acidity and redox nature of the catalysts have an important role in the oxidation of benzyl alcohol and these properties are influenced by the amounts of Cs and V, respectively, in heteropoly molybdates. A plausible mechanism for Cs x MPAV y /TiO2 catalyzed oxidation of benzyl alcohol has been proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of cesium and vanadium contents on the oxidation functionalities of heteropoly molybdate catalysts
